properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northeast outflow winds gusting to 90 km/h have developed over the Fraser Valley this evening as arctic air from the BC interior pushes out to the coast. These strong outflow winds will continue tonight and will ease below warning criteria near noon Saturday, but winds will remain blustery. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T19:14:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T03:15:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1514765146.2020
Area: Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong southeasterly winds expected tonight, as well as higher than normal water levels along the Atlantic coastline. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Rain and strong southeasterly winds will end tonight behind a low pressure system sweeping eastward across the Maritimes. Higher than normal water levels and pounding surf are expected along the Atlantic coast near high tide tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T09:59:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T02:30:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0751679156.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long lasting blizzard conditions are expected to persist into Sunday evening. At Sachs Harbour, strong southerly winds will shift to westerly tonight, gusting up to 80 km/h through Sunday. At Paulatuk strong southerly wind gusts possibly reaching 120 km/h are expected through this evening until the wind direction shifts. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T19:25:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T03:26:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4268854747.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour, Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds across the region this evening. Gusty westerly winds are expected to continue until this evening with peak gusts near 70 km/h. Winds will gradually diminish later this evening. Isolated power outages are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T07:34:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T00:25:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1554921583.2020
Area: Bayfield Inlet - Dunchurch, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter weather conditions will affect much of southern Alberta until Saturday evening. Snowfall, heavy at times, will continue into Saturday, easing in the warned region from west to east throughout the day. Northeasterly winds will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow, lasting through Saturday for some areas. By Saturday evening, total snowfall accumulations may approach 20-30 cm, with regions in southwestern Alberta possibly reaching 40 cm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T19:27:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T03:28:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0728048593.2020

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: southeasterly gusting to 150 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: after midnight tonight until Saturday morning. Remarks: strong southeasterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h will further increase to 150 km/h after midnight tonight and then diminish somewhat and shift to southwesterly early Saturday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at high risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A widespread and hazardous winter storm will affect the western Arctic this weekend. Strong winds will produce poor visibility in blowing snow at times over some areas tonight, Saturday and Sunday. Timing and severity remain somewhat uncertain, however conditions are expected to deteriorate Saturday night at both Ulukhaktok and Tuktoyaktuk. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: generally 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: entire Labrador Coast from Nain to L'Anse-au-Clair and inland to Eagle River. Time span: overnight tonight until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: The snowfall rates will be heaviest on Saturday and will combine with gusty easterly winds to cause widespread blowing snow. Snowfall rates will begin to ease over Saturday night; however, the blowing snow is expected to persist throughout the weekend as the winds shift to strong northwesterlies by Sunday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A blizzard has developed in the community of Kugluktuk and is forecast to last until Saturday morning. During the day on Saturday, it is expected that blowing snow will continue however at this time, blizzard conditions are not expected. Blizzard conditions may once again return to the region Saturday night and last into Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE (March 12, 2020 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-14T17:54:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-14T01:55:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1061561757.2020
Area: Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h except up to 140 km/h along the coast. Locations: the west coast from Channel-Port aux Basques to Gros Morne and the Burgeo Highway. Time span: after midnight tonight until Saturday morning. Remarks: Snowfall will combine with very strong southeasterly winds tonight to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Blowing snow will taper off by Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Under mainly clear skies, wind chill values will be near minus 40 overnight into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T19:27:32-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h except 80 along parts of the coast. Locations: Deer Lake to the Baie Verte Peninsula. Time span: overnight tonight until Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy and blowing snow will begin overnight and then briefly change to showers or drizzle before ending Saturday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-14T13:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T01:28:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0861759734.2020
Area: Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow are expected tonight. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T16:59:01-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 50 centimetres are expected over these regions. This snow will be accompanied by strong to high winds causing blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts causing widespread damage are expected or occurring. Locations: western Newfoundland. Maximum gusts: 90 to 100 km/h, except locally 140 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Time span: tonight until Saturday morning. Remarks: Very strong southeasterly winds will develop tonight then diminish Saturday morning as winds shift to southwesterly. Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Trout River Bay, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-14T13:59:16-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Cold arctic air from the BC interior has reached the Central Coast and is generating strong winds through mainland inlets and valleys. These east to northeast winds will reach speeds of 80 to 100 km/h. The cold air is expected to continue driving these winds through early Sunday. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T16:06:21-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 90 km/h. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: late this evening. Remarks: Southeasterly wind gusts reaching 90 km/h are expected late this evening, particularly along exposed areas of the northern coast. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T07:59:31-00:00
